instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.P5VG3S_EN: What is P5VG3S_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_G3S power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3S: What is PP3V3_G3S? PP3V3_G3S is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3S standby state. .
definitions.P3V3G3S_EN: What is P3V3G3S_EN? P3VG3S_EN is a signal that turns on the PP3V3_G3S power rail. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.USBC_XA_CC2: What is USBC_XA_CC2? USBC_XA_CC2 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.USBC_XB_CC1: What is USBC_XB_CC1? USBC_XB_CC1 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.USBC_XB_CC2: What is USBC_XB_CC2? USBC_XB_CC2 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.USBC_TB_CC2: What is USBC_TB_CC2? USBC_TB_CC2 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V DCIN all LDOs present
threads.message:
Hi guys, 
I got this mac with a little water damage in the QB631 area and RB641 & RB631 were replaced. 
I have 20v in DCIN only with the battery connected but it does not turn on. without the battery DCIN  has 5V and all LDOs are present.

checking without battery i have:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.28 V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> 0.033 V
<SIGNAL>P5VG3S_EN</SIGNAL> 0.0 V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> 3.3 V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3 V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> 0.0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S</SIGNAL> 0.0
<SIGNAL>P3V3G3S_EN</SIGNAL> 0.0

No shorts..

bad <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>?
any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V DCIN all LDOs present
threads.message:
12.28V at USB-C input denotes a communication problem between T2 and <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

All USB-C ports have the same behaviour?
Compare diode mode readings for LDO rails of all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips; also for CC1/2 pins.

See if you can get into DFU mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V DCIN all LDOs present
threads.message:
yeap, all USB-C ports have the same behavior. 20V with battery and charger only 5V just charger.
no shorts found, all diode mode readings are ok in LDOs.

CC1/2 pins.  ?  what is it?
anything else to check before the T2 firmware ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V DCIN all LDOs present
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V DCIN all LDOs present
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V DCIN all LDOs present
threads.message:
Not too big differences.
Do you get 1V1 LDO on each powered USB-C port?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V DCIN all LDOs present
threads.message:
yes, i have all LDOs present, 3.3 1.8 (X2) and 1.1 ( on each port where power is connected)

What could be the reason for 20V in DCIN when battery and charger connected but 5V with only the charger connected?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V DCIN all LDOs present
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V DCIN all LDOs present
threads.message:
2informaticos !!!!
mil gracias !!!

So the T2 firmware fix procedure did the magic.
This mac is now up and running. :geek:
